:orange_heart:*Please take a moment to review our Code of Conduct*:orange_heart:

We want the HubSpot Developer community to be inclusive and welcoming. By following our Code of Conduct, you can help ensure that's the case.

TL;DR:
• Be respectful
• Be inclusive (try not to say, "Hey guys, hey boys, hey [any specific group]")
• No self promotion, except for <#C0121KGC6RM|showcase> and <#CBNDYJJAZ|jobs> 
• No unsolicited DMs
Read the <https://developers.HubSpot.com/slack/code-of-conduct|whole thing here> - and thanks for being a part of the HubSpot Developer Community!

Want to report a violation? DM <@UQNEXHW14> or fill out the <https://form.asana.com/?k=p7aM0fpd3G4JGETDL_nYXg&d=8587152060687|anonymous form here>.

Hello everyone. I've inherited a client who is still on the old style editor for their blog. Is there a method to updating the blog templates to the new DND templates or is this just not possible? I feel like ive read about this in the past but of course I cant find the article now

Hey, guys!!
My team faced the same issue today!
We found the following solution:
Our client's IT team pointed to HubSpot's CNAME, as soon as it worked, they pointed to Imperva's CNAME.
This will cause issues in the future

HubSpot uses Cloudflare which in itself is a WAF and CDN. When you put a CDN in front of a CDN you can experience odd issues: caching issues, sometimes Cloudflare will show the CAPTCHA challenge to users - as all requests appear as if they're originating from one IP.
They have specific docs about how you'd need to set it up here: <https://docs.imperva.com/bundle/cloud-application-security/page/onboarding/onboarding-cdn.htm>

It all relies on the fact that HubSpot's Cloudflare configuration works with the following;

*Note:* This configuration requires XFF header support on your existing CDN. For example, X-Forwarded-For, True-Client-IP, or another header used by your CDN for identifying the originating IP address of the connecting client.
OMG, I'll let my team know about this, thank you!!
Yeah - its worth reviewing - you may not be experiencing these issues but it's always worth double checking as it's not simply a "DNS" issue :slightly_smiling_face:

For some reason the first page of my blog search results is all 404 pages.  Is there anyway to re-index the site to get those broken links to go away?  Support keeps trying to get me to add redirects but I’d rather not have redirects in my search results when those pages don’t exist so they shouldn’t be showing up in the first place.  The broken links are from a temporary blog name that doesn’t exist any more.  It’s been several weeks now and it doesn’t seem like they are just going to disappear on their own.
